Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Student Travel Support Program for the 2017 V.M. Goldschmidt Conference in Paris, France, August 13-18, 2017
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support participation by graduate students in the 2017 V.M. Goldschmidt Conference in Paris, France, during August 13-18, 2017. This travel grant will enable the best and brightest students from the US and US Territories, students who might otherwise be unable to attend due to financial constraints at their home institutions, to benefit from all the advantages this meeting has to offer at this turning point in their respective careers. The Goldschmidt conference is the premier venue for geochemistry and the chosen students will be exposed to the latest advances in the field of geochemistry. The conference offers an excellent opportunity for networking of students who are close to graduation and will be entering the workforce. In addition to oral and poster presentation in 19 theme sessions, students can participate in field trips and workshops associated with the conference.

Applications will be collected from the students, then reviewed and ranked by a volunteer committee of scientists. Twenty-four students, who are presenting their work at the conference, will receive $1,250 each toward travel expenses. Considerations for the award are the preparation of the application package, the demonstrated need for the funds, the selection of a diverse pool of applicants based on gender,representation and geographical distribution. Every effort is made to encourage underrepresented minorities and people with disabilities to apply for funding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to facilitate student participation in the 2017 Goldschmidt Conference by providing grants to assist with travel costs. Students participating in Goldschmidt, the world’s premier gathering of geochemists, have the opportunity to present their research, receive feedback, and interact with leading scientists from more than 50 countries.

The National Science Foundation provided $30,000 for distribution to students from degree-granting U.S. universities. The project proposal included a request to support 24 students’ attendance at the 2017 conference. Grant recipients funded through the NSF award received $1,250 each to support the cost of attending the V.M. Goldschmidt Conference (Goldschmidt2017) held in Paris, France from 13-18, 2017.

Twenty-four (24) students in Geobiology and Low-Temperature Geochemistry received travel grants to facilitate their participation in the 2017 Goldschmidt Conference thanks to this NSF grant. These students attended the conference in Paris, where they presented their results, networked with international colleagues and learned about the latest scientific developments in their disciplines. Students responded on a post-conference survey that the travel grant was significant in allowing them to participate in the conference. Participating in the conference allowed them to learn about the latest research in their particular fields of interest, gain experience in presenting their own research, and receive feedback on their work.

For many students, the opportunity to attend a conference like the 2017 Goldschmidt Conference in Paris influences their decision to continue pursuit of a degree in STEM, with the intention of joining the STEM expert workforce upon graduation.
